column7: Additional Insured - Owners, Lessees or Contractors - Automatic Status When Required In Construction  Contract or Agreement Including Completed Operations - Primary and Noncontributory
ADDITIONAL INSURED - OWNERS, LESSEES OR CONTRACTORS - AUTOMATIC STATUS WHEN REQUIRED IN AGREEMENT WITH YOU
column15: The following sentence limits coverage to the sole negligence of the contractor; which will make it near impossible to trigger coverage for the AI. Exclusion D.1. "This insurance does not apply to "Bodily injury", "property damage" or "personal and advertising injury" arising out of any act or omission of an additional insured or any of its employees."
column16: In almost all claims, there will be some form of contributory negligence, which will either negate coverage outright or create an apportionment issue between AI and insurer.  In addition, for the AI coverage grant they use the narrower "but only to the extent caused, in whole or part" language and in the insurnace does not apply they use the broader "arising out of any act" language.
column23: The following sentence limits coverage to the sole negligence of the contractor; which will make it near impossible to trigger coverage for the AI. Exclusion D.1. "This insurance does not apply to "Bodily injury", "property damage" or "personal and advertising injury" arising out of any act or omission of an additional insured or any of its employees."
column24: In almost all claims, there will be some form of contributory negligence, which will either negate coverage outright or create an apportionment issue between AI and insurer.  In addition, for the AI coverage grant they use the narrower "but only to the extent caused, in whole or part" language and in the insurnace does not apply they use the broader "arising out of any act" language.
column28:
The following sentence limits coverage to the sole negligence of the contractor; which will make it near impossible to trigger coverage for the AI. Exclusion D.1. "This insurance does not apply to "Bodily injury", "property damage" or "personal and advertising injury" arising out of any act or omission of an additional insured or any of its employees."  In almost all claims, there will be some form of contributory negligence, which will either negate coverage outright or create an apportionment issue between AI and insurer.

In addition, for the AI coverage grant they use the narrower "but only to the extent caused, in whole or part" language and in the insurnace does not apply they use the broader "arising out of any act" language.

column7: ADDITIONAL INSURED ? AUTOMATIC STATUS WHEN REQUIRED IN CONSTRUCTION AGREEMENT WITH YOU ?CONTRACTORS ? COMPLETED OPERATIONS
column16: This endorsement may work for some clients, it will likely make sense to review with risk management.
column23:
1. Under A., 1. it reads: "Caused by "your work" performed for that additional insured that is the subject of the written contract or written agreement; and", this language limits the scope of the AI endorsement to just the specific work in the contract.  So any additional work or work deemed outside the scope of the contract will not be covered.  This concerns us since there is almost always work done on site that was not contemplated by the contract or the owner request additional work to be done again that is not memorialized in the contract.

5. Under E., 1., b. and c. it reads:  b. Tender the defense and indemnity of any claim or "suit" to all insurers whom also have insurance available to the additional insured; and c. Agree to make available any other insurance which the additional insured has for a loss we cover under this Coverage Part.  And while there is language further along in the endorsement related to amending the Other Insurance clause to extend the AI status on primary and non-contributory basis, this only applies if the named insured has agreed in the written contract to provide that status.  If the requirement is not in the written contract, then these sections apply and in essence defeats the basic intent of additional insured status of risk transfer to the responsible party (in this case the named insured).
column24: This endorsement may work for some clients, it will likely make sense to review with risk management.

column7: ADDITIONAL INSURED OWNERS, LESSEES OR CONTRACTORS COMPLETED OPERATIONS
column16:
This endorsement may work for some clients, it will likely make sense to review with risk management. The language "but only to the extent that the organization is held liable" is problematic.  We believe this language will limit coverage for the AI to only circumstances where the contractor is solely negligent; which in almost all claims, there will be some form of contributory negligence, which will negate the AI's ability to trigger any coverage under this endorsement.

In addition, the ?held liable? language will make it difficult to trigger coverage until the claim has been adjudicated or a finding of fault has been determined.
column24:
This endorsement may work for some clients, it will likely make sense to review with risk management. The language "but only to the extent that the organization is held liable" is problematic.  We believe this language will limit coverage for the AI to only circumstances where the contractor is solely negligent; which in almost all claims, there will be some form of contributory negligence, which will negate the AI's ability to trigger any coverage under this endorsement.

In addition, the ?held liable? language will make it difficult to trigger coverage until the claim has been adjudicated or a finding of fault has been determined.

column7:
BLANKET ADDITIONAL INSUREDS -
OWNERS, LESSEES OR CONTRACTORS
column16:
This endorsement may work for some clients, it will likely make sense to review with risk management. The language "but only to the extent that the organization is held liable" is problematic.  We believe this language will limit coverage for the AI to only circumstances where the contractor is solely negligent; which in almost all claims, there will be some form of contributory negligence, which will negate the AI's ability to trigger any coverage under this endorsement.

In addition, the ?held liable? language will make it difficult to trigger coverage until the claim has been adjudicated or a finding of fault has been determined.

column15: Many things about this endorsement are unacceptable.

This endorsement form number is the same as another United Specialty AI endorsement titled - ADDITIONAL INSURED-OWNERS, LESSEES OR CONTRACTORS - (FORM B).
column23: Many things about this endorsement are unacceptable.
column24: This endorsement is problematic in so many ways.  Talk with risk management as needed.
column28:
This endorsement has a number of sections which create uncertainty as to the coverage which will be available to the additional insured. The following language is limiting and requires the replacement of this endorsement:
1. "...(2) only if the Additional Insured performs all obligations required under the Policy?""
2. "...only to the extent that the additional insured is held liable for the negligence or strict liability of the Named Insured..."
3. "...No coverage is provided for liability based upon the acts, errors and omissions of the Additional Insured..."
4. "...No coverage is provided to an Additional Insured for damages because of ""bodily injury"" to an employee of the original Named Insured..."

column7: ADDITIONAL INSURED-OWNERS, LESSEES OR CONTRACTORS - (FORM B)
ADDITIONAL INSURED - AUTOMATIC STATUS WHEN REQUIRED BY WRITTEN CONTRACT WITH YOU
column16:
This endorsement is problematic since it only extends coverage to the AI for the operations of the named insured.  The policy is missing the "the acts or omissions of those acting on your behalf" ISO language; which is important if the contractor will not be doing all of the work.

Even if the contractor confirms no subcontractors and that they will be doing all of the work, circumstances on the job site might dictate a subcontractor is hired by the contractor and if there is a claim and the subcontractors insurance fails or is not available, then the contractors policy will not step in on behalf of the AI.
column24:
This endorsement is problematic since it only extends coverage to the AI for the operations of the named insured.  The policy is missing the "the acts or omissions of those acting on your behalf" ISO language; which is important if the contractor will not be doing all of the work.

Even if the contractor confirms no subcontractors and that they will be doing all of the work, circumstances on the job site might dictate a subcontractor is hired by the contractor and if there is a claim and the subcontractors insurance fails or is not available, then the contractors policy will not step in on behalf of the AI.

column7: COMMERCIAL GENERAL LIABILITY CONTRACTORS ENDORSEMENT
ADDITIONAL INSURED - OWNERS, LESSEES OR CONTRACTORS - AUTOMATIC STATUS WHEN REQUIRED IN CONSTRUCTION AGREEMENT - COMPLETED OPERATIONS
column15: Everything about this endorsement is unacceptable.
column16: This endorsement is problematic in so many ways.  Talk with risk management as needed.
column23:
1. "The coverage afforded to the AI is solely limited to liability specifically resulting from the conduct of the Named Insured, which may be imputed to the Additional Insured."
2. "Willful misconduct of or for defects in design furnished by, the additional insured or its 'employees'."
3. "As a condition of coverage, the AI shall be obligated to tender the defense and indemnity of every claim or suit to all other insurers that may provide coverage to the AI, whether contingent, excess or primary."
column24: This endorsement is problematic in so many ways.  Talk with risk management as needed.
column28:
Part A. coverage limitation "...solely limited to liability specifically resulting from the conduct of the Named Insured?"

Part B. restricts coverage as follows '...no coverage to the Additional Insured for liability caused, in whole or in part, out of the claimed negligence of the Additional Insured...'

The condition of coverage stating '... the additional insured shall be obligated to tender the defense and indemnity of every claim or suit to all other insurers that may provide coverage to the additional insured, whether contingent, excess or primary..." is contrary to the intent of additional insured status.

Please replace this endorsement with ISO CG 20 37 or an acceptable equivalent.

column7: General Liability Ultra Platinum Enhancement Coverages
column15: Under A., 2., g. it reads "For purposes of paragraph A. of this endorsement, the terms "you" and "your" refer to the Named Insured shown in the Declarations." This modifies the standard ISO language by removing "and any other person or organization qualifying as a Named Insured under this policy."  This change limits coverage to just the Named Insured shown in the Declarations.  Many companies have multiple named insureds on a single CGL policy that are not shown in the Declarations so if one of those entities entered into the contract with the additional insured, the policy does not extend coverage.
column16: The issue of Named Insured under the policy will need to match the contractor who the contract is with; and while it may work for some clients, it will likely make sense to review with risk management.

column28:
The standard by which coverage for the AI is triggered is raised to negligent acts or  omissions, as opposed to the ISO 'acts or omissions', using the term negligent limits the scope of coverage.

This endorsement limits coverage when the AI shares a portion of the  fault for the claim. In addition
it appears to limit coverage for someone acting on your behalf and acting on behalf of the AI.

(ARCHITECTS, ENGINEERS AND SURVEYORS)
column15:
"1.b. If, and only to the extent that, the injury or damage is caused by acts or omissions of
you or your subcontractor in the performance
of "your work" to which the "written contract
requiring insurance" applies, or in connection
with premises owned by or rented to you."

4. The following definition is added to the
DEFINITIONS Section:
"Written contract requiring insurance" means that part of any written contract under which you are
required to include a person or organization as an additional insured on this Coverage Part,
provided that the "bodily injury" and "property
damage" occurs and the "personal injury" is
caused by an offense committed:
a. After you have signed that written contract;
b. While that part of the written contract is in
effect; and
c. Before the 'end of the policy period
column16:
Personal Injury coverage is included. Advertising Injury coverage is NOT included - see section 1.a.
Whichever is less language applies but does state specifically use the phrase 'whichever is less' - see section 1.g.
Products / Completed operations coverage applies when "spcifically" required by the written contract and is limited the term required by contract "...or the end of the policy period, whichever is earlier..." - see section 1.h.
The endorsement DEFINEs "Written contract requiring insurance" - see section 4
